uses and then you should ask the question of okay how isolated these

is to enable teams like developers data scientists and the operations teams to do an efficient work remember the main

so for experimentation I wanted to touch on K native how many people knows what
canadab is okay just a few again which is good uh K native is associated a lot
with serverless and it's a kubernetes extension that allows you to uh basically scale up and scale down your
workloads something that you cannot do with plain kubernetes is downscale your applications to zero right like just
when whenever your applications are not being used actually removing the container out from from running it's not
something that you can do with kubernetes you can do some manual things with it but okay native takes care of doing that and also like buffering
requests for whenever there are no like replicas of the application running so Kennedy is something that when you have
a kubernetes cluster you can install K native into that cluster to enable that cluster with a lot of serverless
features let's say but it's way much much more than that the first thing that you can do with K
native is something that you will notice is that if uh if you know kubernetes already you know that you need to
understand about what a deployment is what the bot is what the an Ingress is what the service is
what we try to do is we kind of try to encapsulate all these Concepts and manage all these concepts for the users
so with 10 10 likes of jungle you should be able to quickly deploy an application and then have a URL to access to that
application so it's taking a bunch of concerns and managing those concerns for you so in this case I'm showing that but
actually what we are trying to solve here is to try to do more like a container service approach right like
Cloud providers are now all offering you know cloud cloud running Google container services I think it's called
in Azure uh they all have different names but it's pretty much the same it's give me a container I will run it for
you you don't really need to worry about kubernetes or anything at all so this is pretty much what we are trying to do
with Canada it's like a simple demo where just specify your global app container image and then it will run it
for you no matter what it's in there right and I think that it's it's pretty cool because it's simplifying a little
bit of the cognitive load that you know teams needs to understand about kubernetes just to get started faster
but it's also adding a bunch of other features and one of the things that I believe
that enable teams to experiment is the idea of advanced traffic management when you install K native you install also
like a networking layer that will enable you to do a bunch of things that I believe that are really important for
teams and that's pretty much for example running different versions of the same applications at the same time and then
it will allow you to choose how you route traffic to these different versions what you will be enable to do with this is to you know as soon as you
have a new version you can just deploy it you can just let it there and then start rolling out traffic to that
version to see how it goes uh and you can do that like using different approaches one is
percentage-based traffic routing you can say okay you know 80 to this to the stable version and I will slowly start
transitioning traffic you know to the newer version or you can use tag or header base routing where you can say
okay I will create like a specific tag so when people point to that tag it will be redirected to the new version or you
can do header based routing which is basically if my client is setting this specific header Kennedy will read that
header and it will redirect to that version again the idea of enabling teams to keep deploying versions and then you
know having the mechanisms so you can actually try that new version before forwarding all the traffic to it
and as I mentioned before like because it's very associated with serverless if you have HTTP applications that are not
receiving any requests okay native can automatically downscale those applications to zero and it will take
care of buffering requests when you know when they are arriving and there is no replica to answer that request it will
buffer the request wait for the new replica to start and then you know forward the request to be process it it
works in the same way when you need to scale up right like you can actually Define their application the concurrency
policies on how many requests the application can support at the single time and if you're going about above the
threshold you will be automatically scaled up so the demo like the second demo it's uh

cluster that's a container and when you are defining how that application gets deployed you can add a couple of
annotations to the application to say you know I want adapter to take care of some functionality of this application
Dapper will inject a sidecar into that container right so we have a kubernetes
spot that has another container running and that Dapper sidecar is exposing a local HTTP and grpc endpoints for your
applications to interact with so now if you want to store data from your application the only thing that you need
to do is you need to make an HTTP request or grpc request to this sidecar that is running in the same up in the
same context of your application so there is no network call it's just a local call to the same host to localhost
doing an HTTP request from your application if you want to store or read data from a persistent store if you want
to animate a message instead of like having a rabbitmq or a Kafka client embedded inside your application you
just call the Dapper sidecar apis to a median event that simple and because it's it works
there like at the sidecar level exposing HTTP and grpc endpoints no matter which language to use you will have the same
functionality to do all this like shared connect shared functionalities right you
can see also that if one application wants to call another that goal can go through the the precise
as well and that's where you can inject all the resiliency policies for example retry mechanisms and you know and how
